description:
I can't get enough of this place.

The food is incredible, fresh, healthy, AMAZING!

The staff are always friendly. So surprising given how busy it usually is. 

What keeps me coming back? Honestly it's a toss up between the awesome staff and the awesome food.

The vegan options are to die for and I always leave in a good mood. That hot sauce though...I could drink it by itself, so good!
They had an Alfredo special one time...probably a good thing it's not on the regular menu because I would be in everyday and it would rule my life.
Seriously it was that good.
I love this place and the community around it - they just turned 1 and I look forward to stuffing my face here for many more years :)
author: Sarah F.

description:
A healthy low carb haven!

The food: Mix n match bowls are EPIC (try the pulled pork). The crispy brussel sprouts are some of the best I've ever had. And they have bone broth. Oh come on! Who else HAS that?!?

Location: 16th & mission, VERY convenient, but easy to walk right by

Interior: peaceful, relaxed vibes & CLEAN

Staff: VERY kind, patient and fast table service

Bottom line: WORTH it
author: Elena P.

description:
"Aww f*** how'd I let myself get brought to a health restaurant?"

::gets handed a menu, eyes immediately find the drinks section::

Oh AND there's no syzzurp? What in the world is even happening rn.

I keep forgetting the word FITFAM starts w "fit". Guess that's wtf I get for finally attending my boxing homies' weekly group dinner.

More like FMLFAM. Nah jk luh this crew.

Yeah so we had a blast.
My GENERAL TSO CHICKEN was ait.
Either way, as of now seems this place is a weekly staple for me.

BYOB tho? ...? loljk
author: Dan B.

description:
I'm such a kitava convert! When first hearing about the concept I was definitely skeptical... how can something that is lacking so many key ingredients (gluten, lactose, soy, etc) be tasty? Well... it was DELICIOUS!

Beautiful space as well. I like how you order at the counter, pay, and then sit. It's fast casual and a great lunch spot. I ordered the General Tso's Chicken and loved it!!
author: Angelina H.

description:
I found myself here on a Saturday night when a restaurant down the street that I planned on eating at had a 1.5 hour wait for a party of two. Since waiting outside in the cold didn't seem particularly enticing, we instead walked to Kitava after doing a quick search on Yelp for gf/df options nearby. So glad we did! We were able to get a seat immediately, though there were enough people in the place to give off a good dinner time vibe. The first thing I noticed was how friendly the staff was. Like honestly they seemed like genuinely good people. We ordered the grass-fed beef meatballs in pesto sauce, the cubano bowl, a turmeric almond milk drink, green tea, and, for dessert, a brownie and an almond cookie.

The meatball dish felt like a home cooked meal that I didn't know I needed. It was so warming and tasty. Rich but not over the top. Simple flavors but blended nicely together. The cubano bowl (which wasn't mine but I had a little) had really nice pulled pork. Not at all greasy which can be hard to find. Both dishes were super filling and generously portioned. I think the brownie was probably tastier earlier in the day, but to be fair we ordered it at 8:30 pm, half an hour before closing. The almond cookie was really good and I'd definitely get it again. The turmeric drink was delicious and the green tea was as expected, green tea.

So yeah, all in all a great experience. I'll definitely return!
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Nothing says gentrification like an old McDonald's being replaced by a gluten-free fast casual restaurant with kombucha on tap.  Despite the fancy sustainable hipster motif, it's not that pricey (for San Francisco) with most mains between $13-$15.  It's not vegan raw healthy, but it feels like cleaner eating than a carby burrito or slice of pizza nearby.

Pesto Meatballs: Labeled as a "small plate", it's definitely smaller than a meal but much more substantive than an appetizer.  Really liked the tasty and warm pesto.  The ground meat was surprisingly yummy for ground meat, like they used a lot of nice spices and herbs.

General Tso's Chicken: Ok, it's nothing like the sticky sweet and spicy General Tso's Chicken one would find at a Chinese-American joint.  It's more like nice chunks of chicken covered in a light and very crispy batter.  There happens to be a not-sticky-at-all sauce on the side that mainly tastes like soy and vinegar.  The rice was fluffy and had some of that light sauce mixed in it.  The large chunks of steamed broccoli were the only boring part.
author: Adam B.

description:
The General Tso's Chicken and Zoodles & Meatballs won me over!

Kitava's food is pretty good, and I love their concept of being 100% free of gluten, dairy, corn, soy, peanuts, refined sugar & seed oils. It's a great spot for the health conscious and those with dietary restrictions like paleo, Whole30 and GF. The proces are steep but the ingredients are high quality.

The restaurant is more like a cafe setting since there are communal tables. It's a good place to get delivery/take out from as well. It's located near the 16th Street BART station in the Mission so a fairly easy location to find. 

The menu consists of lots of bowl options like the Baja Bowl, Cuban Bowl, and you can also mix and match 1 protein and 2 sides. The Zoodles & Meatballs and General Tso's Chicken are delicious and popular.

I got the Mix & Match with salmon, turmeric cauliflower rice and brussels sprouts and it came out to $19 which was pretty expensive. The portions weren't that big, even though it came in a big bowl which I was sort of disappointed by. The food is kind of on the plain/bland side. Try their specialty entrees instead.

We also got the Immunity Broth which had ginger and turmeric in it which was $5. The broth was way too salty and I couldn't finish it.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
I love chicken wings. For part three of my weekly office lunch, I decided to get some from Kitava. Our delivery arrived via Caviar on Friday, June 22nd around 12:30pm.

I got the Chicken Wings with Ranch and Green Onion: 6 pieces, Pasture-raised chicken wings, tossed with paleo ranch dressing and green onions, over a bed of arugula ($6). I adore greens, so I was happy the dish came with a mini salad underneath. The wings were tasty. Lots of flavor. But they were really small. I don't think an order would fill you up as they are not very meaty. I guess that's what you get with pasture raised chickens? They're skinnier, so less meat?

Their menu offered a lot of comfort food, so I wouldn't mind trying more dishes from here. Plus, their slogan on Caviar said "Healthy Food Without Compromise". Healthy and comforting? Works for me!
author: Elena N.

description:
I came here for a team lunch during the week. I really love the concept of gluten, dairy, corn, soy, peanut, and refined sugar free, however, I felt it was lacking in flavor and most dishes only had a few items in them. I would have liked to have more options (and am willing to pay more for it) available in their dishes. The zucchini noodle dish for instance is just zucchini, sauce and basil (with the option to add mushroom or meat). The Cuban bowl seemed to have more variety in it but the day I was there they were out of beans. 

The space is clean and decor is nice for a fast sit down meal. I'm not sure if this is normal here but it was weird that we all ordered on the same number but our dishes did not come out at the same time. Makes it super awkward for one person to start eating or have their food but have to wait for the rest of the dishes.
author: Tarah P.

description:
I'm wondering to myself why the fuck I haven't come here sooner?

Yes, this place is expensive, and yes, the location is a bit sketch. But believe me, Kitava is so worth going!!! Fresh ingredients, delicious taste, and transparent menu... what more could I ask for? I ended up ordering the General Tso's chicken with cauliflower rice. I wasn't in a rush to eat lunch when I came in, but when the nice waitress and I both noticed that my food still wasn't ready despite having waited for half an hour, she gave me a side of plantains on the house. :) I usually don't eat fried stuff, but those plantains tasted B O M B. What I loved more, though, was the chicken. The breading was thick and crispy, and the chicken meat was juicy and tender. However, the cauliflower rice tasted way too overwhelming. Imo, there was way too much turmeric and ginger for me to enjoy the cauli-rice on its own. But when paired with the chicken, it tasted a little better.

Overall, I love this place, because it's a healthy, fast-casual joint conveniently located across the 16th and Mission Bart station. In the future, though, I might request for the cauli-rice to be cooked plain instead.
author: Connie X.

description: They are VERY expensive. I went there by myself and it came up to 20$. They charge extra for everything. To answer your question of why I didn't feel it was worth 20$ a person: usually a 20$ meal for myself would be a bit fancier. For something from a place like yours, one could usually get an entire meal for 15$. Not have to pay extra for any sides. I
author: Lucinda R.

description:
I love cauliflower normally, and the cauliflower did look extremely rice like. However, the taste was slightly bitter, with a texture that was overly hard. There wasn't any flavoring to it at all, and it imparted the bitter taste onto the rest of the food when eaten in combination 2/5.

The pork add on ($5) was in good portion. While the meat was not dry, a bit more moisture would have been appreciated. The flavoring was sufficient, not overly strong in pork flavor, and felt like a healthy protein. 3.25/5.

The carrot and red lettuce veggie mix was super crunchy-- not a carrot fan normally, but couldn't taste it in this mix. 3.75/5. The beans on this were standard. Plaintains (included with the dish) was cooked through, with a sweet taste and starchy texture. 

Overall the dish felt healthy and was ~1.5 full meals for me. However, I would highly suggest not doing the cauliflower rice, as avant-garde and appealing as it sounds.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Overview: Kitava is a clean, modern, health-conscious, gluten-free, medium sized, spacious, sit down (but serve yourself) restaurant that opened in 2017 located in the heart of the Mission District on 16th and Mission on the east side of the BART station that replaced the McDonalds there.

The Food: About half of the menu items here are a variant of a grain-bowl or a salad bowl, consisting of a protein such as pork shoulder, chicken, or salmon atop a mix of white rice, legumes, vegetables, and avocado. There isn't a specific ethnicity that Kitava adheres to and you can get options from the "Cuban Bowl" that adds plantains, to meatballs/zucchini, to General Tso's chicken, to the house salad which consists of spinach, arugula, cabbage, carrots, tomatoes, and avocado. Prices for an average meal range from about $14-16 and portions are on the heartier side.

In general you will feel good about eating at Kitava as most of the foods served here are traditionally thought of as being healthy and many of their ingredients are organic and locally sourced. On the flip side, Kitava still serves white rice, plantains, fried chicken, and a variety of desserts so to me their vision seems kind of diluted. For example, their Cuban bowl is 871 calories (300 more than a Big Mac), and 47% of your daily sodium content. The Zoodles+Meatballs (for 3 meatballs) is 520 calories, 77% of your daily sodium content. I do get the impression that Kitava is catering more to people on fad diets. 

As for how the food tastes, it's a little low on the flavor, and most dishes are fairly simple. The meats specifically are a bit dry and I found myself needing to incorporate a little chunk of plantain into every bite of my Cuban bowl because the rest of the bowl was on the bland side.

Conclusions: Kitava is a wonderful addition to the Mission neighborhood and I hope that it thrives. If you like the idea of local ingredients, simple bowls, clean, spacious interiors, and hate the idea of gluten, Kitava is a perfect place for lunch with a date or a small group.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I had the local special which consisted of pulled pork and plantains over rice with salsa and it was delicious!

They have a bit of a healthy trend here so the dish could have used a little bit more salt but they have Himalayan salt on the table so it tastes just perfect after you season it yourself.

The pork was juicy and tender, the plantains were delicious, but what actually made the dish taste extra good was the hot sauce like salsa on the table. It's lightly spicy with a nice sweet and sour kick and it really elevates the dish and makes it taste that much better.

I'll have to come back and try their other concoctions, you can get things with cauliflower rice! It looks pretty paleo friendly.
author: Tyler T.

description: My go-to restaurant in San Francisco. Delicious, high quality food, both vegan and Paleo options, accessible to BART. The owners are also great people. Highly recommend.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
I tried Kitava back in the Mealmade days. I found the food tasty and wholesome, but kind of pricey for delivery so I only tried it once or twice. Recently, I ordered 10 meals catered for a group meeting through Caviar and enjoyed it. The food was simple, flavorful, and had a home-cooked quality to it. There's also something everyone with a dietary restriction from gluten free, vegan, keto, the intersection of some of the above.

I also visited the Mission location for a casual weekend lunch with a friend and for a quick dinner. The second time, it was slow to get my order but eventually got it. The food quality is great, and it's nice to have a low carb option with healthy food.

I enjoy the build your own plate (main protein) plus two sides. I love the brussel sprouts side, crispy, deep flavor and rich aioli dipping sauce. I could easily eat it as a meal!
author: Truc N.

description:
I was in town this weekend and I'm so glad someone in a group found this place! The decor is beautiful, It includes plants, art and some living walls. There was even a cooking class going on in the back, which was cool to see. 

They had two different kinds of kombucha on tap. I liked the lemonade ginger one better. 

This place was nice because I feel like they has something for everyone on the menu and had so many healthy options. Three people I went with were on a keto diet (mainly protein and meat) and I am on a plant based diet. But we were all able to have a meal here. I was impressed with their dessert menu. They had sugar free options and dairy free options as well.  The vanilla bean gelato is cashew based (vegan option) and it is a must try! 

I was surprised they have only been opened since September. The staff was really nice and helpful answering all of our questions. I can't wait to go back. 

Pros: Clearly marked vegan/veggie options on the menu, sugar free desserts, decor/cute art on the wall, nice music, friendly/knowledgeable staff, cooking classes available, and they have wifi 

Cons: I can't think of any..I wish they had more locations?

Tips: If you're a fan of kombucha, try their kombucha on tap, they give out free samples. Also read the card about what the name of the restaurant means! :)
author: Carly E.

description:
4.5 stars. Love this spot in the mission. The ingredients are right on and the flavor/ are right on. And it's even better that this is at the site where McDonald's was - time for people to upgrade into a new healthier spot. Casual healthy food served more affordably to the masses - reminds me of Digg in New York. I hope that they will expand to downtown SF soon!

I ordered the Cuban bowl with braised pasture-raised pork, cauliflower, cumin beans, kale slaw, avocado and rice. This one has the right texture with the soft and tender pork and rice with the more crunchy cauliflower, kale slaw, and sunflower seed risotto. Even though there are literally 10 wholesome ingredients in this dish, the dish tastes incredibly natural and balanced. I love the slight Indian influenced spices integrated into the bowl.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I got a pork dish - it was well balanced (rice, salad, pork); the pork was well cooked.
author: Margaret R.

description: Salad with roasted chicken and half an avocado was just the thing to feel satisfied after a long day of small meals and hardly any snacks. Hard to believe the place used to be a mickeyDs before. Step outside and you're back in familiar mission and 16th but corner is full of cameras
author: tomohisa w.

description:
Cool spot on the corner of 16th and Mission. 

Hopped into this place recently and went with the:

Pesto Chicken Cobb $15 - Roasted Chicken , sunflower basil, pesto, bacon, egg , avocado, tomatoes ,spinach, dairy-free ranch dressing with extra virgin olive oil

Took a number and waited patiently for my meal.

I like Pesto and like Cobb Salads and this was a good solid salad but I was not blown away. It's in the middle of my tier below but it has a great location so I could see myself picking up another salad sometime. 

I like Healthy Foods...occasionally ...lol. For the past year or so I workout multiple times everyday so I typically try to eat at least one Salad a day. Often times I bring my own salad for lunch but sometimes I venture out in the city for some healthy greens.  

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. 

Here is a look at how I rank the Salad Spots in the City. They are all pretty good this is just my take. 


Rod's San Francisco Salad Rankings (and what they're known for or what I like). I have rankings various foods like Boba, Ramen, Steakhouse, Chicken and Wafffles(random right?) Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews. I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places 

Ranked from Fave to least fave (Business owners don't hate me, all these places are good) 

1 Café du Soleil-Nicoise Salad
2 SweetGreen-Pesto Chicken
3 Darwin Café-Baby Spinach 
4 La Fromagerie-La Mancha Salad
5 Mission Picnic -Deluxe Cobb
6 Mixt-Mixt Cobb
7 Plutos-Custom salad
8 Tender Greens-Chinese Chicken
9 Blue Barn Gourmet-Cobber (Cobb Salad)
10 Split Pea Seduction-The Squash salad
11 Boxed Foods-Boxed Chicken Salad
12 Kitava-Pesto Chicken Cobb
13 Soma Chicken-Caesar Salad
14 Proper Food-Lemon Quinoa Salad with Chicken
15 Eatsa-Various Salads/bowls 
16 The New Spot on Polk-Asian Chicken
17 Organic Coup-Kale/Caesar Combo 
18 Uno Dos Tacos-Fish Salad Bowl
author: Rod M.

description:
My boyfriend and I are on the Whole30 diet right now and were looking for suitable dinner options. I searched "paleo" in Yelp and this was one of the first few options. I saw at the top of their online menu that everything was Soy/Dairy/Wheat/Yadda Yadda free and said "Yep this is the one".

It's right across from 16th & Mission BART so very centrally-located and was easy to get to. The atmosphere is very chill, casual, and relaxing with the order at the counter/seat yourself/bus your own table flow which is gaining so much popularity here in SF (a whole other conversation). Also sharing tables with strangers is definitely somewhat expected just because it's a small place with lots of chairs at each space to eat. This must be a newer business cause the bathroom looks like it was still being set up and you have to super hulk strength one of the stall doors in the women's bathroom to get it to close.

Everything was well-priced and super delicious! I came with two people and we all ordered different things and tried each other's stuff.

Brussel sprouts + aioli were a nice thing to munch on, I loved how crispy they were. It's hard to mess up brussel sprouts, imo.

General Tso's chicken was not to be missed, what a great take on a classic. I love that they use coconut aminos for the sauce instead of soy. We ordered this w cauliflower "rice" instead of the jasmine rice and were pleased that this was even an option (it's like they really know their audience or something~).

The meatloaf and mashed sweet potatoes were also very good, I've never had sweet potato that tastes so similar to your expected mashed white potatoes. They were savory and delicious.

The spaghetti squash bolognese w/ beef was soooo satisfying. My boyfriend didn't want to get this at first (which I understand, cause like yeah, spaghetti squash subbing in for actual pasta is almost like carob pretending to be chocolate) but it was very rich and flavor-complex and I kept bugging him by saying "and you didn't want to get this one! Ha!".

I left with that pleasantly full, content, and warm feeling that only follows an especially nourishing meal. My mouth is watering just thinking about it and I'll definitely be a returning diner.
author: Megan D.

description: One of my new favorite spots in sf. I love everything about this place. The fact that they give back to he community is super great and something that other restaurants should learn from. The staff was super friendly and the food was incredible. It's hard to find delicious, healthy food in the city and that's why I'm so glad that I found Kitava. I ordered the Cuban bowl which was delicious but I'll definitely be back soon! Everything on the menu sounds delicious.
author: Ina S.

description: I love the Cuban bowl. Such a great mix of flavors and the atmosphere is extremely good !
author: Jonathan L.

description: Love love loved all the food we had. Health conscious foodies dream location. Paleo Treats are sold here  Vixen Kitchen ice cream  100% gluten free and dairy free  yessss! My boyfriend loved it too and he's not GF DF like me. Area is a little sketch but that was expected. Bathroom needs work. Good friendly staff.
author: Amanda M.

description: I ordered takeout and the food arrived on time but I just didn't love the way it tasted. I ordered spaghetti squash with mushroom bolognese and a "Mix and Match". The brussels were delicious (5/5), the spaghetti squash was ok (4/5) but the sweet potato mash tasted like pure sugar (2/5) and the pasteurized chicken was terrible because it was all diced up and ended up being about 95% skin with a tiny bit of dark meat (1/5). Perhaps other items on the menu are better but I was not thrilled with the items that I ordered.
author: Kate M.

description: 100% free of Gluten, dairy, corn, soy, peanut, refined sugar and seed oils! They get me! I've never been in a restaurant that offers an AIP menu. If you have food sensitivities, this is the place for you! Plus the ingredients are pasture-raised, grassfed, etc! I can't tell you how excited I am about it. And it was delicious. General Tso's chicken was delish and the chocolate brownie... sooo chocolatey. Service was excellent too. Just a lovely experience. I want to come back everyday. I'll be by in the morning for some bone broth for sure!
author: Dede S.

description: I just ordered food off grub hub. I'm in San Fran for work and eat paleo. It's hard to find good clean spots. Omg omg!!  I had the Cuban bowl. I loved it so much. I just ate it so fast!! I wish you delivered to Seattle!
author: Rebecca G.

description: My friends were in town for weeks getting treated for cancer. Mykel was so sweet to them, which is such a blessing when you are going through such a difficult time. Thank you Mykel!
author: Pam H.

description:
What a great place for people looking for a healthy option. Kitava caters to people who are looking for a paleo meal, including those on an AIP (auto-immune paleo) diet. 

I recommend ordering the Cuban Bowl with pulled pork or General Tso's Chicken. You can substitute the rice for cauliflower tumeric rice.

Oh, the brownie is pretty bomb, too!
author: Lindsey K.

description: I'm obsessed with this place. It's a gluten free vegan Mecca, and they even have meat options for my friends that aren't into vegan fare! The avocado mash with yucca chips is a must, they have kombucha on top, and their mashed sweet potatoes are the best I've ever had! I like to get a mix and match bowl, but the mashed sweet potatoes and phenomenal Brussels sprouts are always included! And the desserts? Literally to die for. This place better be around for a long time, because I can't get enough.
author: Melissa M.

description:
If it tastes bad, it must be good for you and if it tastes good, it must be bad for you - right?

Then again, maybe it's just a rhetorical question and the answer is right in front me. 

*Stares at thunder thighs* 

What can I say? I love good food but sometimes I want a clean meal for balance.

The last time I tried a very restrictive, health-oriented eatery, I never wanted to look at a vegan, gluten free, lo-carb, no sugar meal again. Don't get me wrong, vegan can be good but this particular place made steamed broccoli for life seem more appealing. 

And, then I read Eater SF's article: "Mission McD's Reborn as Gluten-Free, Paleo Restaurant": http://bit.ly/2iReSAn. GF, paleo friendly chicken nuggets, french fries, and sweet & sour sauce?! I'm so there! 

Ok, I can't be the only one who misread the misleading title. I mean, if McD was going to reborn into anything "health-conscious", it's first location would definitely be in the hipster Mission. 

Sorry, to disappoint McD fans but taking over the vacant McD space is Kitava is paleo friendly, fast-casual restaurant that's free from dairy, corn, soy, peanuts, refined sugar and oils. Meats are grass fed and pastured.

On the menu are small plates (butternut squash hummus, pesto meatballs), salads, bowls (Cuban bowl, zoodles & meatballs, General tso's chicken) and sweets (brownie, cookies, ice cream sandwich). 

Like most new eateries in the city, it's not cheap but not insanely expensive either. A bowl and a brownie was about $25 including tip. Not an everyday type of place I can afford to go to for lunch but Kitava is THE place to go to when you're seeking a tasty meal that's makes you feel good about yourself. 

They also offer delivery through UberEATS, DoorDash, and GrubHub.

I ordered at the counter with the very friendly cashier and my meal was ready within minutes. 

For lunch, I choose the Cuban Bowl ($14) w/ heritage pork shoulder, plantains, avocado, kale slaw, cilantro-garlic mojo sauce, cauliflower rice & sunflower risotto (+$2): http://bit.ly/2mnkLu4.

This was a very filling bowl with a good ratio of proteins and fiber. 

The pork shoulder was fantastic - slow cooked and very tender. Much better than nearby Media Noche's rendition. Mojo sauce added a great acidity and the plantains had a nice caramelized sweetness. I love heat and each table had a bottle of housemade tangy habanero sauce. It wasn't too hot so don't worry. 

I wasn't too keen on the cauliflower rice (very cabbagey with a bitter aftertaste) and sunflower risotto (like oatmeal). They do have pink Himalayan sea salt on each table that will probably help neutralize the cauliflower rice but I didn't use it. Personally, I like a more neutral flavor you get with regular rice but that's just my AZN side. Next time, I would just do all kale slaw or the white rice & beans option. 

I've had my fair share of terrible, GF desserts so I was very pleasantly surprised at how tasty the Dark Chocolate Brownie ($4): http://bit.ly/2zDpi0g was. It's made with almond flour, pastured eggs and coconut sugar. It was very chocolately and satisfying. Not chalky. 

The owners have done a great job revamping the space and turning it into an inviting, bright space with living succulents and greenery on the walls. 

Kitava is easily accessible from Bart which is right across the street. Street parking is very tough. 

If you're looking for a quick, filling, and healthy meal that's packed with clean, high-quality ingredients that doesn't sacrifice on taste, check out Kitava!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
If you are in San Francisco, let me assure you that making an effort to stop at Kitava is well worth any time and energy spent. Located in the heart of Mission District, Kitava is a modern cafe that offers appetizers, small plates, entrees, and desserts that have been expertly prepared using only the highest quality of ingredients (i.e. pasture-raised meats and safe cooking oils). Is it healthy? Yes. Is it delicious? Yes.

My husband and I easily walked to this restaurant with an infant and stroller in tow from Mission Delores Park, but one can also directly access it via the BART station across the street. Upon entering Kitava, we discovered a spacious atmosphere decorated in a simple, yet tasteful manner. Guests order at a main counter and then dishes are delivered to your table of choice. After examining the menu, my husband ordered the Cuban bowl with pastured heritage pork shoulder, and I chose the General Tso's chicken. There was a tempting $7 special of the day, but we chose to try some of the restaurant's acclaimed staples. 

Our food was delivered within 20 minutes, an impressive feat considering the restaurant was full of patrons at 2:30 p.m. on a weekday afternoon. My General Tso's Chicken was beautifully displayed atop a bed of fresh broccoli and jasmine rice (can substitute with cauliflower rice). I wish I had taken a picture, but the aroma was too tantalizing. Within minutes, my plate was empty! The chicken was perfect - crispy and flavorful, but made without using any gluten, soy, MSG, etc. My husband reported his dish was equally delicious. And the best part? We felt GOOD about our choices. This is definitely a restaurant we would like to eat at again!
author: Arielle C.

description:
UPDATE: 

Originally my review had a lower amount of stars, however, I decided to update it. I noticed that my salad also didn't have the promised Pepitas and decided to talk to stuff directly. The lady I was talking to was very nice and compassionate, and was very responsive to feedback. She said she'd pass it onto her boss and agreed that this was unacceptable. They refunded my salad and gave me complimentary yuka chips and hummus. I'm happy to see that they handled it so well and hope to see the salads get better. 

I also noticed that their bowls looked really nice and as I pointed out earlier, I haven't tried anything BUT the salad so my opinion is based solely on that.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

If you want a literal salad (a pack of arugula and spinach mix) with a topping of 3 blueberries and 2 tiny pieces of avocado for $12, this the right place for you! 
I got the California salad (one of their specials) and it was REALLY disappointing. I could have gone to a grocery store and get a pack of salad mix on my own for a cheaper price. 

AVOID their salads! Can't speak for anything else, but the salad sucked A LOT.
author: Luba Y.

description: This place is delicious! Everything tastes wonderful, you would never guess it is health food. And all ingredients are listed online so I know exactly what I am eating. I wish there were places like this in other cities!
author: Jenn W.

description:
This place is hands down my new favorite place to eat in the mission. The food is fresh and yummy! It's satusfying without being filling. You leave feeling satiated and proud of your life choices. 
I had the vegan Cuban bowl. I wanted the cauliflower rice but the cashier misunderstood and gave me regular rice. (It's okay, just a reason to go back). My boyfriend had the Baja bowl with salmon and we got a side of brussel sprouts and plantains. I also had the lemongrass kombucha which was the best kombucha I've ever had. 
Everything was fresh and the salmon tasted like natural caught salmon. 

10/10 will go again. 10/10 will recommend to everyone.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
I'm excited about any restaurant establishment that offers health conscious food, ethically sourced, and most importantly, flavor driven. 

As natural as possible, Kitava offers gluten-free, no refined sugars or flours, dairy free, corn free, soy free, peanut free, and seed oil free. They also use grass-fed and free range meats. 

My faves are the General Tso Chicken over a bed of cauliflower rice. I've had plenty of their other selections too, but this is probably the best that they offer. The bone broths are good, but not seasoned enough. I do LOVE their avocado mash and accompanying yucca chips. Brownies are great too. The Spaghetti Bolognese is a crowd pleaser. Totally love it. 

Paleo and Whole 30 friendly. 

Bomb dig.
author: Ann S.

description: Fantastic bowls! I had the General Tso's with cauliflower rice. It was excellent. My wife had a mix and match with pork, kale, and brussel sprouts. Also great. Very clean, great ambiance!
author: Brad E.

description:
Finally there's a great place in the Mission to get affordable, low-carb, healthy food! Kitava (formerly Mealmade) serves up delicious entrees and appetizers that are easy on your waist and wallet. 

I ordered Kitava through Grubhub for delivery, but you can also order via UberEATS for delivery, Grubhub for pickup, or just dine in. 

The Kitava website lists out all of the potential dishes you can order and the best part is that clicking on each gives you the full picture of nutritional info so you can really get an idea of what you're eating. Huge plus points for this! Also, many of the meat dishes can be made vegetarian, which is great! 

Kitava is one of the few places in SF serving low-carb alternatives to noodles, namely zucchini noodles and spaghetti squash. I love that they have these options!

I decided to order the Zucchini Noodles ($14) with Meatballs. This dish was truly excellent! I make zucchini noodles myself and I must say, it is pretty hard to get them cooked to perfection - not overly crunchy but also not too cooked otherwise it gets mushy. Kitava cooks them so well! The sauce on this dish was so flavorful. Sure, it's a simple sauce, but it just tasted so fresh. The meatballs too were flavorful, juicy, and also cooked well! 

I can't wait to order again from Kitava and try more of their dishes!
author: Sabina S.

description:
I've heard nothing but good things about this place, so I figured I must try!

First impressions:
- Very clean location
- A variety of different options
- A bit pricey, but worth it
- HEALTHY

I was born and raised in San Francisco's Mission District, and it is so so hard to find healthy food. The menu seemed a bit intimidating, but I was happy with my first order ever here.

My mother ordered the Baja Bowl ($11) with chicken (+$4)
- Extremely Tasty
- Comes with: Guac, some sort of really good veggie mix, pico de gallo, salsa, beans, and white rice + the chicken she added on which was extremely flavorful!
- Big portion

She also tried the Chicken Bone Broth ($5)
- She absolutely loved it, just stated that it was critical to add her own salt and pepper to make it a bit tastier!

I ordered the General Tso's Chicken ($14)
- I wasn't absolutely in love with it, but it wasn't bad. When I come back, I'd probably order something different
- It is very flavorful, and a big portion

To end we tried the Vanilla Bean Gelato ($6) and Dark Chocolate Brownie ($4)
- Gelato was bomb
- Brownie was okay!

I definitely saw other dishes that I want to try and overheard people saying they absolutely loved! Would definitely recommend. Right now this place is at a 3.5/5 for me, but I think that will quickly change once I try some new things!
author: Kassie E.

description: Delicious food. Kind and quick service. Great vegan, vegetarian, and meat dishes. Food is fresh and organic. Loved it.
author: Cristian G.

description:
I ordered the orange chicken with cauliflower rice with extra sauce. No extra sauce. Dry. Only a few pieces of stale and cold chicken.  Small and not 1/2 full in container. For $16

Ordered plantains. These were not included. 

Cookie. Dry tasteless cardboard.

Food arrived 1/2 hour late. At first- Refused to redeliver- had to go thru grub hub and be on the phone for 45mins.  

So finally get a redeliver. No sauce with plantains and no extra sauce. Two 1/2 filled container that could only cover some chicken.

Wanted to love this place. Disappointed.
author: meesh m.

description:
I understand that broccoli is healthy, but really though, how much broccoli can a human eat in one sitting? I'm gonna have to rent a pickup truck to load all this broccoli out of here. I'm not talking about just some broccoli on a plate, I'm talking about massive bunches of broccoli that you practically need a machete to get through. No human being should be expected to chew through that.

I'm willing to pay for healthy food, but I've given up on this place. The quality and quantity of the food just vary too much from order to order. Ordering the chicken dish, one day I'll get a good size portion of meat, the next day I'll get a few tiny nuggets and THREE TONS of broccoli... I've ordered the extra chicken option, ok?; but again, sometimes there is a good amount of extra chicken, other times you just feel violated. Maybe eating at the restaurant in person is different, I've only ever ordered for delivery. I just can't take it anymore.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I stumbled upon this place coming up from the BART on 16th and Mission while trolling around the city by myself, waiting to hop on a plane back to Vegas. My phone was on it's last leg, as was I. We both needed to recharge. 

There are booths and tables of all different sized to accommodate your party, however big or small it might be. Don't be shy to share a table (and/or an outlet!). It's clean in terms of actual cleanliness and decor. More on the modern, sleek side but comfortable. Water is free and is self serve by the register. They let me fill up my Nalgene for the trip. Thanks!

Eating out while maintaining a clean/paleo/gluten+dairy free diet is freaking hard. Especially when you're in an unfamiliar city. I was grateful to stumble upon this place. I was shocked that I could eat most everything without drastically modifying it and getting judged by cashiers/servers. 

The cashier totally helped me out with suggestions. I was grateful for that. I let her know that I had never been there before because I was just passing through but really needed to eat before I had to head back to the airport. She suggested a special that was going on, the pork and plantain bowl but subbed with kale slaw instead of rice. SCORE!

It was out of this world. The pork was tender, the plantains gave way to create the perfect balance the savory pork and the spiciness which is the sauce in the squeeze bottles on the table. Amazing. 

I left this spot with a heavy heart, wishing that we had somewhere like this at home. Hope they stick around. I'd definitely make it a point to stop back the next time I'm in the area!
author: Amy E.

description:
Every dish was delicious, and they were so kind to accommodate a large and complex order for 12 of us (including vegans, and carnivores on keto diet.)

I love the lack of bad ingredients here, all the chemicals and additives and garbage foods you normally see in food these days are not on the menu! Yes, I salute this mission! (pun intended, due to restaurant location?)

I really like the bowl options, and they offer so many delicious foods and also accommodate really difficult diets like paleo, keto and vegan.  That and they taste great!

The sides were very good too, the plantains were lovely and soft.

The only thing I disliked was the (cassava?) chips and guacamole because the chips were not crisp, but felt soft and malleable like an 'old' potato chip does when left out for a few days. That may have just been an outlier.
author: Jules F.

description: I can't believe I've waited this long to come in here! Super keto friendly. Delicious food. I'll be back!
author: Kim P.

description:
Wow! Amazing food and all really healthy! The only negative is that the area is pretty sketchy, but ok in the daytime. 

They work with various delivery services, and this will become a mainstay for me going forward!

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Laurence N.

description:
Love them! Zoodles, meatballs, and meatloaf are all favorites in our house. It's a great, healthy go-to when we are tired and want take out. 

They list all their ingredients and have great options when deciding if you want paleo, gluten free or whole 30. 

It delish and you get a good value for the $$$. Highly recommend!
author: Terri L.

description:
I found Kitava one day when I was  Googling places in the city to get Zoodles.  Kitva is fairly new, I think it opened late last fall.   I brought my friend who is gluten free, dairy free, meat free, sugar free, blah blah blah and she loved this place so much that she now goes there all the time.  I think it's a good place to go with extremely health conscious people.

To me Kitava is expensive for my budget but it's not overpriced.  For the quality of food you are getting it's reasonable yet if you are on a tight budget it might be too much.  They do have daily specials that are around $7.  Some other options if you don't want to spend a lot are the plantaines ($5) which are really filling and the avocado mash ($6) which is like chips and guacamole but way less heavy.  

My favorite thing about Kitava is that the food isn't heavy and you don't feel weighed down and lethargic like food at other restaurants. Everything especially the meats are very flavorful, everything is fresh, and their portion sizes are more realistic as to what people this day in age should be eating.  

I'd recommend their zoodles with meatballs, general Tso's chicken, and chocolate covered dates.  

It's right across from the 16th and Bart so can be doable during lunch if working in the financial district downtown time because it's easy to get to.
author: Joan W.

description:
I actually heard about Kitava through an even where they catered the food, and I am so glad for the discovery. Kitava is now one of my favorite spots in SF and a staple in my rotation. Here's why:

The food is fresh, additive free, and best of all DELICIOUS. The entire place is gluten and dairy free, which is amazing. Most items can be made completely grain free and paleo and/or vegan, another huge win. Despite being a huge foodie and lover of all things delicious and bad for me, I spend the vast majority of my time eating paleo. I'm so thankful to have a place that is incredibly tasty, has a varied menu, and is healthy for a wide range of diets. 

Here's what I've had-
Butternut squash "hummus" - it's a bean free revelation. It has an amazing combination of comforting warming spices that I've tried to replicate at home but I can't. Safe to say I'm completely obsessed and addicted. 

Meatball appetizer - I remember enjoying this when I tasted it at the event but can't remember specifics. 

Spaghetti squash bolognese - very tasty! Spaghetti squash /= pasta but I really enjoyed this dish and was satisfied by the portion. Great hearty dish for the cooler winter weather we've been having lately. 

Cuban Bowl - love that I can sub more slaw for the beans and the offer cauliflower rice. This bowl is SO GOOD. Plus the pineapple habanero hot sauce is a great match for the fresh tangy flavors in the bowl. Also the avocado that came in the bowl was perfection - a HUGE pet peeve of mine is getting under/over ripe avocados. I'd honestly rather not have it at all if it's not just right. 

Brownies - omg these are so good. I'd be eating them right now if I wasn't doing w30. 

I didn't try the meatloaf that m boyfriend had but he seemed to really like it and finished his plate!

Yes, this place is a bit pricey but if you're willing to pay a premium to know you're putting good food in, it shouldn't bother you too much. And honestly I'd rather support places with a mission like Kitava.
author: Sam L.

description:
Saw this spot when looking for gluten free food in the area and was glad to find this paleo-friendly place! Then I also happened to see a gilt deal for a dinner for two here, so me and my boyfriend sprang on it. We came on a Saturday night; the place is across the street from the BART station and doesn't have a lot of tables. Most tables were full, but we were able to find a spot after we ordered our deal of an appetizer, two entrees, and a dessert to share.

We ordered the fried brussel sprouts as our appetizer, Meatloaf and sweet mashed potatoes as our first entree, General Tso's chicken as our second entree, and brownie as our dessert.

Even though the sprouts were our appetizer, they came out after the entrees so it was treated more like our side. As far as fried Brussel sprouts go, they were fine; if they didn't come with the aioli then they'd essentially have no taste, hardly even salt, so I would not consider ordering it again unless they added some spices.

The meatloaf plate was good. Good flavor and a good healthy version of a hearty meal. Especially since half the dish was steamed broccoli and carrots so I'd suggest asking for more sauce or gravy.

The chicken was weird. We thought they they might have messed up the sauce on our order because it was supposed to be a soy sauce-like coconut aminos sauce, but it tasted like balsamic vinegar. It even came with an extra serving of the sauce, but we didn't use it with the chicken - honestly, it went better with the Brussel sprouts like a balsamic glaze. If it weren't for the sauce, the dish seemed like it could be pretty bomb...

The dessert was so so; the consistency was very crumbly which I'd expect for something gluten free, but I've made so many gluten free, paleo friendly brownies in my day that I was expecting better.

Overall I was pleased with the concept and experience and would come back to try different things and stay away from others. The staff was nice, but could be more informed about the choices when trying to find something that fits your dietary restrictions and taste.
author: Samira I.

description:
3.5 overall but has a lot of potential if they work out the kinks. I really want this place to improve because I did like many things about it. It is conveniently located near Bart. It is one of the few paleo/primal friendly restaurants. I follow primal for health reasons and have friends who do as well so it is great to look at the menu and not have to figure out which meal we can eat. The service was friendly and it was clean inside. The sauce that came with my dish was delicious. The breaded chicken was hot, crispy, and tasted great. My friend really enjoyed her dish overall in terms of flavor.

The rice for both of our dishes were uncooked so they had a slight crunch to them. My breaded chicken was hot but the rest of my food came out warm and quickly turned cold. I guess someone in the kitchen finished cooking and placing the rice and broccoli in bowl way earlier than when the chicken was done. The ratio on my dish was a bit off. There was a lot of rice but I would have liked more broccoli and chicken pieces. The amount of chicken pieces I got was much smaller than the amount of broccoli I got. Pretty soon I was just eating a bowl of sauced rice because I ran out of chicken and broccoli.

I really hope this place gets better because if it does, this place can easily become a go to place for me as a lunch or dinner choice so I am willing to give it another chance. Crossing my fingers that the next visit will be a five star experience.
author: S A.

description: The first thing I notice is the space. So we coming and modern! I love the community tables. Second the staff here are awesome. Really positive vibes from everyone I talked to. The food was quite good too! I was really impressed by the commitment to different types of dietary needs. I got the zoodles with king trumpet mushrooms. The zoodles and the marinara sauce were really good but unfortunately the mushrooms were a under done, hence the loss of a star. Great experience overall though.
author: Jacob S.

description: I've only been here once so I haven't tried too much off the menu, but my first experience didn't leave me very excited. To start on a positive note, the concept is good, the space is clean and nice, and the food quality is good. Now onto the other stuff... I came in wanting to have a meal with spiced beans but they were out of beans. I ended up getting the zoodles and sauce with king trumpet mushrooms. The tenderness of the mushroom chunks was inconsistent - some were soft but many of them were pretty rubbery and hard to bite into. I didn't finish them. The dish was lacking in flavor. I ate with two other people who each got the Cuban bowl. They liked it but also commented on blandness. While I don't see myself heading to the Mission just for another meal here, if I'm standing at the corner of 16th and Mission and am looking for a quick bite I would be open to trying another dish.
author: Russ S.

description: Nice food! Very nice place! Wish they just put key dressing sauce in the Pesto Chicken salad
author: Tram N.

description:
I think we can all agree there's a lot of great food in the Mission - I can barely walk 5 paces without bumping into something delicious that I want to eat. But Kitava is something pretty different; healthy, tasty food that is veggie-forward while still offering some excellent meat options. 

I went in for the first time with low-moderate expectations on the taste front, but I was blown away by how well cooked, well seasoned, and downright delicious everything was. It's obvious a lot of care, thought and love is put into this food and the produce used to make it.

So far I've tried:

- Zoodles and meatballs: I'm Italian and fancy my family meatball recipe as kind of a big deal. THESE MEATBALLS WERE BETTER.

- General Tso's Chicken: a healthier version of the finger-licking fried dish we all love. Except this batter is made from cassava flour and so doesn't make you feel bloated and oily. Served on rice with bright green broccoli. A little light on the chicken pieces when I tried it, but the whole portion was large and very filling.

- Cuban bowl (see photo here: https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/kitava-san-francisco?select=c6N7Y3V8deF37oI66DMy-g): I've tried this with the pork, chicken and also meatless, and each time it's been so so tasty. I sub in the cauliflower rice + sunflower risotto, both of which are delicious, and I have never been able to finish the bowl. *chef kissy fingers*

The space is beautiful, the staff is knowledgeable and there's really nothing else like it in the area. Try it before the ever-growing crowds get too intense.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Kitava is a rare gem in this city, in that they take unbelievable care in making sure that their food is well sourced, and that it is good for you as well. All of their dishes are gluten free, they serve organic meat and vegetables, and they use sustainable palm, avocado, coconut, and olive oil in their dishes.

I have yet to actually visit Kitava's physical location, but I have had delivery from here a number of times (including when they used to be known as Mealmade). My favorite dish of what I've ordered so far -is their meatloaf, which comes paired with sweet potato mash, roasted vegetables, and a dreamy chicken broth based gravy. Their crunchy brussels sprouts are also divine. In fact just last night  - I ate two big orders of them. So good! I appreciate that Kitava uses wild salmon in their fish dishes - and normally salmon would be my go-to order here, but I have yet to be wowed by the way that they cook it here. It's never very moist and it doesn't have a ton of flavor.

If you're looking for healthy food that has been cooked with quality ingredients - Kitava is your spot. I'm looking forward to exploring more of their menu in these next coming weeks.

Trust
author: Jessica T.

description:
1st time here. Thank you for using exceptional ingredients and providing another healthy option in a city that seems to love hedonism :-)

Please open a 2nd location in the inner sunset! You would do very well.
author: Mark C.

description:
Came here after purchasing their dine-in deal for 2 on Gilt with high expectations as my gf is gluten free. I ordered the General Tso chicken with Brussels sprouts as an appetizer. The sprouts were solid, nothing super special. The chicken itself was good, especially for being gluten free. The weird part was the sauce - it basically tasted like balsamic vinegar which didn't go with the chicken at all. Not sure if this was a mistake or not, but can't recommend the dish because of that.

I'd consider coming back to try something else when I'm in the area and needing something gluten free.
author: Matt D.

description: Got the general tso's chicken with white rice to go. I felt the rice was a bit undercooked I think. Chicken was tender and tasted good. Also got the brownie which was not overly sweet which I  prefer. I'm definitely going back and will try the Cuban bowl and the bone broth and everything else on the pictures posted here on Yelp. This place reminded me of Little Gem in the Hayes Valley (from a fast casual dining perspective) but Little Gem's more expensive.
author: Michael Angelo R.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here for a while because i was so excited for a healthy place to go out. This review is based on food only as i ended up ordering for delivery. A coworker and i ordered the avocado salads and neither one looked like any of the pictures. It was mostly arugula with 4 small slices of avocado on top and drenched in lemon juice. I also ordered the Brussels sprouts (which were overpriced for the amount...$8) but pretty tasty. The cauliflower rice was ok but not much flavor. My coworker ordered the cookie with the drizzle. Can't comment on the taste of that but it was just a cookie. Didn't come with any drizzle. Disappointing.

And adding after the response of the owner since it doesn't seem like you can reply. You missed my point on the avocado salad. The point is they weren't anything like the picture of the menu online nor the pictures other patrons have posted. That means we received  way less avocado (definitely not a half) than your normal portion. Sorry i didn't take a picture.
author: Nicole A.

description:
When I can order off a menu with no substitutions, I'd give 'em 10 stars if I could. Worth the walk for me....General Tso's chicken with Jasmine rice was incredible and finally quenched my craving for Chinese food. 

The ice cream sandwich was a taste of heaven for me and it felt great to finally be able to have a dessert while visiting SF. 

Portions were big enough that I had leftovers to make a second full meal. 

THANK YOU to the owner for opening this amazing restaurant!
author: Heather R.

description: It's hard to find lunch spots that are this veggie friendly and healthy without paying out the nose, and this place nails it. Adding salmon is crazy expensive, but if you're down with just veggies it's an excellent deal.
author: Dylan J.

description:
Man it feels good to eat great! Service was quick, food was exceptional, and if they didn't tell you it was paleo and gluten free, you'd never know. 

I recommend the Brussels Sprouts and Meat Loaf, as those were specifically what I ordered. Meat loaf sounds basic but they took it to another level. This was my first experience with mashed sweet potatoes, and they were amazing with a gravy that paired excellently with the meat loaf. 

Casually dine out or order in, either way you won't regret it!
author: Julius B.

description:
3.5 stars.

Gluten free, paleo restaurant and is perfect if you're doing Whole 30 and looking to eat out (no dairy, soy, sugar, gluten/grains). It's expensive, but it's unavoidable due to the high cost of the ingredients, like using coconut aminos instead of soy sauce or cassava flour instead of flour.

I got Kitava delivered (they are on Caviar, GrubHub, UberEats, and Doordash) and ordered the General Tso's chicken with cauliflower rice (extra $) since I felt it was the dish that I was least able to make myself (unlike the spaghetti squash bolognese). The breading was surprisingly crisp, and the dish overall was pretty filling. A few of my chicken pieces were dried out and stringy though, which is why I didn't rate it higher.
author: Alice T.

description:
Now this was an excellent find thanks to Yelper extraordinaire Cherylynn N. who was so simpatico with my recent wave of healthful eating that she pointed me in the direction of this spanking new organic spot which ironically took the place of a very tired-looking McDonald's right outside of the 16th Street BART station. It's a deceptively casual operation where you order at the counter and wait for the food with your number on a stick. I say 'deceptive' only because the prices are higher than you would expect, but the quality of the dishes more than justifies the cost. It was a bit like Chipotle if it went into a health nut phase and then went for a makeover. I really like the concept a lot because this is the type of fast food we all need to move toward if we plan to lead healthier lives. I came here quite early after work. so there wasn't a customer in the place, just what looked to be an employee eating at the one large round communal table.

I had already taken a sneak preview of the menu online, so I knew what I wanted to try. It was the $15 Baja Bowl which mixed an avocado mash, kale slaw, poblano peppers, pico de gallo, salsa verde, and upon my discretion, cauliflower rice since I'm trying to minimize my carb intake. It automatically came with pastured chicken which pulled apart with ease (photo: http://bit.ly/2A0aLwe) - but you can alternatively order wild-caught salmon or cumin-spiced beans if you're a veg-head. I thought it was quite delicious and very fresh-tasting, and the portion was reasonable without getting excessive. The Chipotle parallels are unavoidable, but I doubt I'll look at another burrito bowl with as much fondness. Because I was like a kid in a candy store (an ironic analogy indeed), I also tried the $11 Pesto Meatballs just because they sounded good.

Nothing veggie about them, as they were made with 100% grass-fed beef and ladled with sunflower basil pesto (photo: http://bit.ly/2A0baz2). That was tasty and it had been so long since I had actual red meat, it was almost intoxicating to my system. There were no soft drinks served here (so much for refills), so I went for the $4.99 REBBL Maca Mocha Coconut Elixir, which was a "super herb-powered coconut-milk elixir with dark cocoa, chicory & maca" (photo: http://bit.ly/2ApiIM9). It was libation enough for me, and you just can't go wrong with coconut in my book. I need to bring Jamie W. back with me next time because he loves General Tso's Chicken and he will be thrilled to know that it comes with cauliflower rice as well. I really hope this place is a raging success because we need more healthy chains like this one. Keep rockin' it, Kitava!

FOOD - 5 stars...bright, fresh, and tasty bowls of goodness...and the meatballs are very good, too
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...very clean and streamlined to match the menu, no elaborate décor here
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...very friendly and very skinny...I hate 'em
TOTAL - 5 stars...considering the convenient location, this will become a go-to spot for me
author: Ed U.

description: I loved the clean ingredients used to make each meal! They have the best designed menu in the area, making it easy to tell what meal would be best for your diet Gluten Free, Nut Free, Paleo, Whole 30, low carb, or vegan. The best part is they use palm oil to cook in, even with the fried plantains and Cassava chips! Even the quality of the meat is great using 100% Grass Fed Beef, pastured pork, or Wild caught salmon. I got the Cuban Bowel with cauliflower rice and my friends got the Baja Bowel and the General Tso's chicken. We also shared the Avocado Mash with Cassava Chips, Fried Plantains, and Butternut Squash Hummus. I'd say they were all great, except for the fried plantains. Overall I loved the meal and will go back often. I highly recommend this place if you care about health!
author: Hanah T.

description: I ordered the Cuban bowl for delivery via Caviar. It gave me the worst case of food poisoning I've had in a very, very long time. Never again.
author: A E.

description:
Have never eaten at the location due to its sketchy location but have ordered delivery service. I'm sure it's safe but just don't want to deal with all the street life at the intersection of 16th and Mission.

I've ordered the zoodles and meatballs, General Tso's chicken, and a dark chocolate brownie. All were very tasty, fresh, gluten-free and healthy. I usually order here when I have spur of the moment, gluten-free dinner guests.
author: Charlie T.

description: Such a great and unique selection of gluten- and dairy-free food! Make sure you try Baja Bowl, my personal favorite. Service is very good and personal.
author: Alina S.

description:
I am an extremely picky eater who HATES vegetables but I am still dreaming about Kitava's brussel sprouts.

When I think of a place to eat that embodies the spirit of San Francisco, Kitava is it. Occupying the space of a former McDonald's, it is beautiful, airy, calming, and kind with warm and friendly staff members who give back to the community.

We shared a plate of the brussel sprouts and Cuban pork. As a picky eater, I figured I'd be able to take a few bites of the pork and avoid everything else on the plates (especially the dreaded veggies), but ended up eating every single bite, or trying to - it was wonderfully filling. The brussel sprouts especially were a standout; they were almost more like potato chips than anything else. We paired them with kombucha on tap, which was surprisingly smooth and non-vinegary.

I never thought I'd be so excited by healthy food. But Kitava makes it approachable and casual.
author: Season H.

description:
I like what they're doing here. Hard to find a restaurant in this city that combines healthy food with hearty dishes and lots of flavor - which is pretty surprising given the California culture. There's something for everyone on the menu and you'll be happy knowing you put something good in your body. 

The decor inside is warm and inviting, great for groups or a casual date. Good music plays overhead and friendly staff. 

I'm giving this 4 stars because with any new restaurant there are things to tweak. For example I ordered my meal to eat at the restaurant but it was packaged to go. The avocados in my Cuban Bowl were not ripe and were rather hard. And, to be frank, spending $20 on my one dish was a bit more steep than I would have liked. I realize you pay for quality ingredients here but do note you should expect to pay more than your average fast casual restaurant. 

Overall I left full and satisfied. Big up to the habanero pineapple sauce too, but add some more heat!
author: Jon G.

description: I drive into the city from the east bay just to eat here. Where else are you going to find an entirely allergy free restaurant (soy, nut, gluten, and dairy free) with heritage pastured pork and grass-fed and finished pastured beef? (In the US beef can be labeled grass-fed so long as they're eating grass the last 30 days prior to slaughter). I believe the owner started this place after getting well from personal health challenges through proper food and nutrition. As someone with food sensitivities and health challenges myself, I really appreciate having a place like this where I can dine out safely. The area can be quite dodgy, especially across the street, but it's worth trekking through the urban jungle once in a while, pungent odors and all, to get high quality clean eats.
author: Tien H.

description: SUCH a good find in SF!!! Loved that this fits with my personal food lifestyle. Loved the main meals but the desserts were my favorite- went back for more!! Ice cream sandwich was my personal favorite! If I lived in SF I would be here often! Service was very friendly and helpful!!
author: Amy M.

description: I ordered delivery from here, and was pleasantly surprised. This dairy and GF life is ruling me, so I'll be ordering from here more frequently. I ordered the pork entree, and the salsa it was bathed in, made the dish. Cumin beans, to keep my microbiome in check. Thank you.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
My new favorite restaurant in San Fran! The food is amazing, the staff is attentive and efficient and the ambiance is great. 

We ordered the pesto meatballs, Brussels sprouts, avocado mash to start. The meatball are out of this world. For our main courses we had the Cuban bowl, General Tso's chicken, Baja bowl and Spaghetti Squash Bolognese. For 4 people it was more than enough and everything was incredibly tasty. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Andy D.

description: A surprising find right by Mission & 16th. Super cool quick and healthy, it's far better than many of the alternatives nearby. Trying to remember what was here before. Was it a McDonald's? The only similarity is that this place serves food fast and there's no table service. Otherwise it's kale and brown rice for you here, except... it's soooo tasty. You should try it out. I know I'm going to keep coming back until I've tried everything on the menu!
author: David A R.

description:
If you eat keto or paleo, once in a while you really need to take a break from cooking every day, right?

Enter Kitava. They have you covered right down to every last ingredient. Try the Avocado Salad -- so refreshing and filling.
author: Christina M.

description: I found this place by yelping "paleo" or maybe "keto" to try to find healthier food options near my office in the mission. I cannot say enough about the food and service. Employees were kind and the food is so delicious. General Tso's chicken was crispy and perfect. Spaghetti squash and beef bolognese was so wonderful and I LOVED the cuban bowl. I ate here 3 out of 3 days on my last work visit to SF. Also, they sell Paleo Treats, a paleo desert company based in San Diego (where I live) so I've already visited them here =) Great coffee, too. Plus I loved the clarity of the menu online so you know exactly what you're getting (awesome for people eating categorically) Can't wait to come back!
author: Shvonne A.

description: Food was very healthy and delicious. I had the Butternut Squash Spaghetti with Mushrooms.
author: Kenji M.

description:
Yeah, it's kinda pricey. But where else are you getting your fast casual bowl with cauliflower rice or zucchini noodles? That's what I thought.

As others have touched on, pricing precludes this spot from being an everyday destination, but I *really* like what I've had here. The Baja Bowl with pastured chicken, avocado mash, kale slaw, poblano peppers, pico de gallo, salsa verde, cauliflower rice & extra kale slaw (instead of beans) has become my go-to, as it's packed with flavor while also being fairly guilt-free. Plus, while I might not be vegan, paleo, or gluten-free, I definitely appreciate the options Kitava has accommodating these lifestyles.
author: Sam H.

description:
Kitava (formerly Mealmade) is a lunch and dinner delivery service (Monday-Friday) which focuses on all the healthy buzzwords of the moment: 
* 100% grass-fed beef, free-range poultry and sustainably-caught seafood
* Organic produce
* Gluten-free EVERYTHING
* No soy, no canola oil
* Paleo (mostly; they have some dairy & grains in some dishes but they identify them for you)
* Low glycemic sweeteners and healthy fats
* Nutrition info, full ingredient lists and photos for all offerings

They cook their meals to order and deliver fast, usually within a half hour. For delivery, they use either GrubHub ($2.99+Delivery fee) or UberEats ($4.99, tip optional), or DoorDash (cost depends on what you order, but I think they're the costliest delivery option). You also have the option to pick up your meal from their Mission location using GrubHub. 

I've ordered from them 20 times since November 2016. They really impressed me with their honestly great-tasting food and they have not forgotten a single item or messed up any orders. In short, they are on the frigging ball. The only tiny, very tiny, quibble I have is that it would be nice to request they bump up their spice level on some of their dishes -- but I understand that in order to please more palates, they keep their seasonings on the gentle side. 

They even cook Thanksgiving lunch and dinner -- I got it last year and it ROCKED. The turkey was moist. The mashed cauliflower was creamy and delicious. The sausage and apple stuffing was pure comfort food (gawd, I love stuffing). Even the Brussels sprouts were tasty, and they are not at all my favorite vegetable. Oh, and the cranberry relish was tangy and zingy. Lastly, the pumpkin pie was rich and decadent. 

Seriously the best delivery service I have had so far in San Francisco. They don't have junky foods (mmm, donuts) or cheesy pizza that I crave sometimes, but for the "healthy" stuff, they got it going on. Oh, and their customer service is *excellent*.
author: Sarah J.

description: Very cool place.  Once you step in,  you are in anotber dimension.  Sane, chill, relaxing-that's just the atmosphere.  The gal at the register was terrific and patient with us newbies.  I had the big cuban bowl with shredded pork and a few slices of avocado, side of coleslaw with kale, cauliflower rice, beans-so delicious and healthy.  The general zhou's chicken was with cauliflower rice and broccoli.  The best is the roasted butternut squash hummus with non-greasy yucca chips.  To top off the meal the ginger lemongrass komacha was so good.  Better than a beer.  The server was wonderful too.  Order at the register, get a number, and they will bring it to you.   Lots of people order to-go.  This place makes me feel healthy.
author: Helen L.

description: Lots of vegan and vegetarian options. Just. In addition to whole30. Staff is friendly and conveniently located in the mission district right next to 16th street Bart station.
author: Madhu J.

description:
Ever since I discovered Kitava just a few blocks away from my office this has become a staple in my lunch rotation. Great space with plenty of seating for groups of various sizes, orders come out really quickly (even during the lunch rush), and the food is very healthy and delicious. I've tried about half of their main dishes and I've enjoyed every one. I really like the "build a bowl" option, and the zoodles+meatballs is delicious and surprisingly healthy "comfort food." The plates are always much larger than I expect and I rarely finish an entire meal. Which is crazy given that everything is super healthy - proof you can live the paleo life and not feel like you're still starving at the end of a meal.

I also appreciate the staff's focus on ingredients and helping people to find dishes that meet their dietary restrictions. This is somewhere I can easily bring my vegan, w30, paleo, and allergy-riddled friends and everyone can find something that works for them. I have a serious nut allergy and whenever I mention this the staff are quick to read through all of the ingredients in a dish and verify that it will be safe for me to eat. It's nice to go to a place where I  don't feel like I'm inconveniencing anyone. Also having easy add on options for cauliflower rice and other dietary adjustments is super useful.

This will continue to be a go-to lunch spot!
author: Alissa B.

description:
I was doing an autoimmune paleo protocol and needed some flavor, and this is one of the few places in the city that I could go to without modifying everything I ordered. They have an AIP menu that's only slightly limited compared to their regular menu. 

The servings of yuca chips plus avocado dip were very generous! I got the general Tso's chicken, it was delicious! Fried chicken is not something I get to eat often... I've also tried the pulled pork and meatloaf before. No symptoms afterwards, so all a good sign!

I would advise against the cauliflower rice because it gave off a weird noxious smell.
author: Maymie C.

description:
Whole 30 approved! 

Love this place. Pretty affordable dishes 10-15$ for items such as Zucchini & Meat Balls. Recommended
author: Kevin L.

description: So excited to find a place to eat!! Loved the fried plantains, Cajun bowl, cookie and brownie!
author: Shannel J.

description: I like the whole food, paleo style approach, the people who work here are good people. The food is nourishing and wholesome I loved it!
author: Jules H.

description: I was so excited to find Kitava on a recent trip to SF for work. I eat mostly Paleo, and Kitava is one of the few restaurants I've found where I didn't have to modify my meal to make it Paleo. I ordered the avocado mash w/ yucca fries, the spaghetti squash bolognese, and a pint of ginger kombucha, which they have on tap. Everything was delicious, and I had enough bolognese leftover for lunch the next day. It was easy for me to hop on BART, and Kitava is right across the street from the 16th Street station. I didn't try dessert this time, but I will definitely be back soon.
author: Tara T.

description: This place is amazing, yummy good for you food. I had the zoodles and meatballs and the guacamole and yaro chips they where both amazing. The cashew maple ice cream is to die for!!
author: Hope A.

description: I had the General Tso's Chicken with Cauliflower and the Butternut Squash Hummus with Yuca chips recommended by Jazmyn. :) thank you for being patient and kind with me and making such delicious recommendations. :) I love the different selections Kitava has and knowing it's all 100% Gluten free ... even the DESSERTS :) doesn't make me feel guilty. I didn't get to try any desserts but it's a must for my future visits. I would highly recommend don't forget to ask Jazmyn anything for she makes amazing suggestions with 5-Star customer service!
author: Veronica T.

description: Haven't written a yelp review in years, but felt inspired by how great this place was! Nice to find somewhere with low carb options and REAL food! No soy, gluten, or any of those irritating ingredients. I felt energized and healthy after eating here, and it tasted delicious. I should mention again - TASTED REAL! Definitely will be coming back next time I'm hanging out in SF. Cuban bowl with pork was quite instagramable as well (just a bonus).
author: Sweden C.

description: Delicious healthy food that leaves you satisfied (but not bloated!)  Clean, simple, and friendly.  Try the Cuban bowl--a wonderful mix of sweet plantains to round out the protein.  My wife loved the Gen Tso chicken.  Highly recommend.
author: James C.

description: What a hidden-in-plain-sight healthy gem! I got the Cuban bowl with cauliflower rice and sunflower risotto and a rebbl beverage- love how all is local, creative, flavorful and fresh. I'll definitely be back!
author: Stephanie T.

description: I LOVE this place. Amazing AIP menu that makes it easy and safe to eat without concern. I eat here at least once a week if not more. Probably my fave restaurant and would very much recommend to anyone who is following an AIP diet and is in the Bay Area.
author: Alix R.

description: This is such a convenient eatery for good quality food. I had the Baja bowl on my most recent visit. Since I'm not a fan of either cauliflower rice or white rice, I opted out for plantains instead. I only wish that they have brown rice as an option. The portion size is moderate, but the food is very filling and dense! You will definitely feel full afterward. Don't forget to on some of that delicious habanero pineapple sauce that comes in a squigee bottle.
author: D W.

description:
I take friends here who are health freaks / "clean-eaters" / have digestive issues. I love the General Tso's chicken and the bone broth but feel like a lot of the dishes need some work (especially given their price point). I highly recommend. HOWEVER, when I ordered the "make your own plate" with chicken ($15), the chicken was so dry that it got stuck in my throat. I had two options: wash it down with a drink or feed it to my friend's pet dog. Not ideal. The roasted Brussels sprouts and cauliflower were also undercooked. A shame, because I love those vegetables! (I tried the fried Brussels sprouts and those were much better)

Also the cookie is VERY DRY. You will also need to wash it down with a drink. Do not order it, unless you are desperate for a cookie (which, if you are gluten-free & paleo, you might be).

The ice cream is very good. But expensive.
author: Natalie S.

description: Kitava has an incredible menu that's accessible to people with all sorts of dietary restrictions.  The staff is incredibly accommodating and has a book on hand with all the information about what's in each dish.  I also signed up and took a cooking class there, which was wonderful! The whole place has a very community-like feel.
author: Stephanie B.

description: I'm in love.  And it's in my hood. I've been aching for a paleo spot in SF. (Move over Little Gem.) The food is delicious, healthy, affordable. Unpretentious. ALL GOOD. Please go here, order big, and let's make them wildly successful. YUMMMMMMMMMMM
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is an update from a previous review.  In my previous review, I gave them four stars, after having tried two of their meals: Baja Bowl and Cuban Bowl.  I had mixed feelings about the food, but was pleased there was a paleo/gluten free place to go to in the Mission.

I went back this Friday to give Kitava another chance, since it had such good reviews on yelp.  I ordered General Tso's chicken (best reviewed) and was sorely disappointed.  The rice was undercooked and the chicken was not filling or particularly tasty.  I was also underwhelmed by the chocolate brownie for dessert.  In sum, I would say Kitava is not worth it for the price, but if you're in the area in a pinch, the food will do.
author: Jordan K.

description:
Came here last night for the first-time. Disclaimer: I eat fairly healthy, but nothing this health-focused generally. I usually eat lots of meat and I'm not afraid of carbs.

So while everything on the menu here isn't necessarily for me, I can still respect it. Kitava is still a pretty cool concept, especially given the rising demand for vegan, allergy-friendly, and gluten-free options. 

I had the Spaghetti Squash Bolognese. It's a really nice dish, especially for pasta-lovers (roasted spaghetti squash noodles, bolognese sauce, fresh basil). If find yourself hungry and looking for a slightly heavier dish (relative to other stuff here), this is a good pick.

The plaintains are also dope. Don't sleep on those!! 

The vibe in here is truly friendly and relaxed, almost in a coffee-shop sort of way. Not sure if that's a good or a bad thing, just an observation. It's differently different than your usual Mission dinner spot, but I found it to be a very chill place to eat.

Only minus is that the seating in here is a bit sparse and hard to find. We had to wait a few minutes to get a table, and even then we seemed to get lucky with the timing. I'd imagine this means your ability to find a seat really boils down to luck more than anything else. So just be aware that if you're planning to dine-in during peak dinner hours, grabbing a table might be a bit tricky.

But all-in-all great meal! Would certainly come back.
author: Brian S.

description:
